description._content: Potlatch As an extension to my work and its engagement with the vast nature of "things" that shape our experiences, and how they resonate on a personal, social, and spiritual scale, I've created a table inspired by the Potlatch tradition of the Northwest Native Americans, in which the host's possessions are given away or destroyed to display wealth or enhance prestige during a ceremonial feast. The table's décor is woven together with my hand from materials both cherished and discarded. Each guest will take part in the degradation of the work by the simple act of enjoying the feast upon tablecloths carrying impressions of my body and each guest will be given parts of the centerpiece, which is comprised of bricks and bundles, fabric and collage, ribbon and paint, as representations of the wealth I have to offer. The Brooklyn Ball 2011 celebrates the art, creativity, and influence of Brooklyn artists and the Museum’s role as a cultural gateway. This year’s Ball is being designed in partnership with Brooklyn artists to create an evening filled with art, ideas, and surprises. Felicia Wong photo, Brooklyn Museum
